  <!-- newsletter signup --> 
  <script>
			/**
			 * Sets cookie for later use in custom variables
			 * @param name custom variable's name
			 * @param value custom variable's value
			 */
			function pianoSetCustomVariableCookie(name, value) {
				// Get all existing values from the cookie
				var cookieValue = pianoReadCustomVariableCookie();
				// Set the value
				cookieValue[name] = value;

				// Get cookie expiration date in 3 years
				var d = new Date();
				d.setTime(d.getTime() + (94608000000));
				var expires = "expires=" + d.toUTCString();


									var domain = 'techcrunch.com';
				
				// Write the cookie value
				document.cookie = "__pcvc=" + JSON.stringify(cookieValue) + ";" + expires + ";path=/;domain=."+domain;
			}

						

			/**
			 * Sets cookie for later use in custom variables
			 * @param name custom variable's name
			 * @param value custom variable's value
			 */
			function pianoSetCustomVariableCookie(name, value) {
			    // Get all existing values from the cookie
			    var cookieValue = pianoReadCustomVariableCookie();
			    // Set the value
			    cookieValue[name] = value;

			    // Get cookie expiration date in 3 years
			    var d = new Date();
			    d.setTime(d.getTime() + (94608000000));
			    var expires = "expires=" + d.toUTCString();

			    // Write the cookie value
			    document.cookie = "__pcvc=" + JSON.stringify(cookieValue) + ";" + expires + ";path=/;domain=.tcpreprod.com";
			}

			/**
			 * Read values from cookie and convert them from json
			 * @param specificName (optional) Name specific value from the set
			 * @returns {*} If specificName is specified - returns single value, otherwise returns JSON object with all values
			 */
			function pianoReadCustomVariableCookie(specificName) {
			    var cookieValue;
			    try {
			        // Try to get the cookie value with regexp
			        var match = document.cookie.match(new RegExp('(^| )__pcvc=([^;]+)'));
			        if (match) {
			            // If cookie with this name was found - try to parse the JSON value
			            cookieValue = JSON.parse(match[2]);
			        }
			    }
			    catch (e) {
			        // By default - set value as empty object
			        cookieValue = {};
			    }
			    if (!cookieValue) {
			        // By default - set value as empty object
			        cookieValue = {};
			    }
			    if (typeof specificName != "undefined") {
			        // Get the specific value from the set
			        if (typeof cookieValue[specificName] != "undefined") {
			            return cookieValue[specificName];
			        }
			        return null;
			    }
			    return cookieValue;
			}

			/**
			 * Function to send data upstream to Piano template
			 * @param iframeId - Element id of the Piano iframe
			 * @param success - true/false. Status of the message
			 * @param message - Error message text
			 * @param object - Additional data, like the the field that triggered the error
			 */
			function sendPostMessageToPiano(iframeId, success, message, object) {
			    var iframe = jQuery('#' + iframeId);

			    if (iframe.length) {
			        iframe[0].contentWindow.postMessage({
			            piano: {
			                success: success,
			                message: message,
			                object: object
			            }
			        }, '*');
			    }
			}

			tp = window.tp || [];

			tp.push(["addHandler", "customEvent", function (event, b, c, d) {
			    switch (event.eventName) {
			        // Don't show me this again
			        case 'dont-show':
			            pianoSetCustomVariableCookie('dontshow', 'y');
			            tp.offer.close();
			            break;

			        case 'tc-signup-newsletters':
			            console.log(event);
			            var email = '';
			            if ((typeof event.params.email != 'undefined') && (event.params.email.length > 0)) {
			                email = event.params.email;
			            }

			            var object = '';
			            if ((typeof event.params.object != 'undefined') && (event.params.object.length > 0)) {
			                object = event.params.object;
			            }

			            var list = [];
			            if ((typeof event.params.list != 'undefined') && (event.params.list.length > 0)) {
			                list = JSON.parse(event.params.list);
			            }

			            var iframeId;

			            // We are parsing the params object sent from the template to find out which iframe triggered it
			            params = JSON.parse(event.params.params);
			            // And here's the iframeId we're looking for
			            iframeId = params.iframeId;

			            //grab the security string from the from the form
			            //on the page, needed for check in the backend
			            var $form = jQuery('.form-newsletters');
			            var url = '/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php';
			            var nonce = $form.data('nonce');


			            if (email == undefined || email == '') {
			                return;
			            }

			            var emailLists = [];
			            for (var i in list){
			                if (list[i]){
			                    emailLists.push(i);
			                }
			            }

			            var jqxhr = jQuery.get(url, {
			                action: "newsletters",
			                subaction: "subscribe",
			                email_lists: emailLists,
			                email: email,
			                tracking_id: event.params.tracking_id,
			                security: nonce
			            }, function (data) {
			                if (!data.success){
			                    sendPostMessageToPiano(iframeId, false, data.data.message, object)
			                }
			                else{
			                    // When the email was added - set the cookie
			                    pianoSetCustomVariableCookie('newsletter', 'y');
			                    sendPostMessageToPiano(iframeId, true, "");
			                }
			            });
			            break;
			    }
			}]);

			// Read all values from cookie
			var cookieValues = pianoReadCustomVariableCookie();

			for (var i in cookieValues) {
			    // Set custom variables from cookie
			    tp.push(['setCustomVariable', i, cookieValues[i]]);
			}



		</script>

  <meta class="swiftype" name="content" data-type="text" content="Today at TechCrunch Disrupt NY, our own Darrell Etherington sat down with Ford Motor Company CTO (and Ford employee since 1987!) Raj Nair to chat about the future and how a company like Ford shifts with an evolving industry — particularly as the car industry adopts the idea of cars that drive themselves. While the overall panel was about autonomous vehicles, they started off with a quick mention of the GT — Ford's ridiculous (both in its ridiculous performance and in the ridiculously low number of them being made), $450,000 supercar. We spent an afternoon checking out the GT a few weeks back. “Yeah.. that car is a little bit my baby,” said Nair. “But it’s kind of the opposite of a driverless vehicle.” Nair elaborated on this a bit later when Darrell asked if we’d see a 100th anniversary GT (as this new GT is a 50th anniversary celebration of the original) — effectively, whether or not Ford would still be making human-driven vehicles in 50 years: Technology is…">

	var setAdblockerCookie = function(adblocker) {
	    var d = new Date();
	    d.setTime(d.getTime() + 60 * 60 * 24 * 30 * 1000);
	    document.cookie = "__adblocker=" + (adblocker ? "true" : "false") + "; expires=" + d.toUTCString() + "; path=/";
	}

	script.setAttribute("onload", "setAdblockerCookie(false);");

        <div class="fb-send-to-messenger" id="fb-send-to-messenger" messenger_app_id="1678638095724206" page_id="8062627951" color="blue" size="large" data-ref="tcnav"></div> 
        <script>
		  window.fbAsyncInit = function() {
		    FB.init({
		      appId      : '1678638095724206',
		      xfbml      : true,
		      version    : 'v2.6'
		    });
			FB.Event.subscribe('xfbml.render', function() {
				jQuery('.fb-messenger-loading').detach()
			});
		  };

		  (function(d, s, id){
		     var js, fjs = d.getElementsByTagName(s)[0];
		     if (d.getElementById(id)) {return;}
		     js = d.createElement(s); js.id = id;
		     js.src = "//connect.facebook.net/en_US/sdk.js";
		     fjs.parentNode.insertBefore(js, fjs);
		   }(document, 'script', 'facebook-jssdk'));

		   function getCookie(name) {
		      var matches = document.cookie.match(new RegExp(
		        "(?:^|; )" + name.replace(/([\.$?*|{}\(\)\[\]\\\/\+^])/g, '\\$1') + "=([^;]*)"
		      ));
		      return matches ? decodeURIComponent(matches[1]) : undefined;
		   }

		   window.onload = function() {
		     var gravity_guid = getCookie('grvinsights');
		     var btn = document.getElementById('fb-send-to-messenger');
		     if (btn != undefined && btn != null) {
			   btn.setAttribute('data-ref', gravity_guid)
			 }
		   }

		</script>

         <h1 class="alpha tweet-title">Ford CTO Raj Nair on the future: Ford will look very different in 10 years</h1> 
         <div class="title-left"> 
          <div class="byline">
            Posted 
           <time datetime="2017-05-15" class="timestamp">11 hours ago</time> by 
           <a href="/author/greg-kumparak/" title="Posts by Greg Kumparak" onclick="s_objectID='river_author';" rel="author">Greg Kumparak</a> 
           <span class="twitter-handle">(<a href="https://twitter.com/grg" rel="external">@grg</a>)</span>
          </div> 
          <!-- Begin: Social Share Icons --> 
          <div class="social-share social-share-inline"> 
           <ul class="inline-list social-share-list" id="social-share" data-permalink="https://techcrunch.com/2017/05/15/ford-cto-raj-nair-on-the-future-ford-will-look-very-different-in-ten-years/" data-shortlink="http://tcrn.ch/2pQ1b6e" data-sharetitle="Ford CTO Raj Nair on the future: Ford will look very different in 10&nbsp;years" data-post-id="1490522" data-twitter-hash="#TCDisrupt"> 
            <li class="total-shares"> <h5 class="total-shares-count">0</h5><br> <small>SHARES</small> </li>

           <div class="less">

         <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2017/05/15/helloava-launches-a-chatbot-for-personalized-skin-care-recommendations/" class="next-link" data-omni-sm="art_nextstory"> 
          <div class="next-story-link">
           Next Story
          </div> 
          <div class="next-story-full"> 
           <h4 class="next-title">HelloAva launches a chatbot for personalized skin care&nbsp;recommendations</h4> 
          </div> </a> 
        </header> 
        <!-- End: Article Header --> 
        <!-- Begin: Article Body --> 
        <div class="l-two-col"> 
         <!-- Begin: Article Body - Main --> 
         <div class="l-main-container"> 
          <div class="l-main"> 
           <div class="article-entry text"> 
            <!-- Begin: Wordpress Article Content --> 
            <p></p>
            <div id="attachment_1490503" style="width: 690px" class="wp-caption aligncenter">
             <img class="size-large wp-image-1490503" src="https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2017/05/tcdisrupt-ny17-8811.jpg?w=680&amp;h=453" alt="" width="680" height="453" srcset="https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2017/05/tcdisrupt-ny17-8811.jpg?w=680&amp;h=453 680w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2017/05/tcdisrupt-ny17-8811.jpg?w=1360&amp;h=906 1360w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2017/05/tcdisrupt-ny17-8811.jpg?w=150&amp;h=100 150w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2017/05/tcdisrupt-ny17-8811.jpg?w=300&amp;h=200 300w, https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2017/05/tcdisrupt-ny17-8811.jpg?w=768&amp;h=512 768w" sizes="(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px">
             <p class="wp-caption-text">Raj Nair (Ford) at TechCrunch Disrupt NY 2017</p>
            </div> 
            <p></p> 
            <p id="speakable-summary">Today at TechCrunch Disrupt NY, our own Darrell Etherington sat down with Ford Motor Company CTO (and Ford employee since 1987!) Raj Nair to chat about the future and how a company like Ford shifts with an evolving industry — particularly as the car industry adopts the idea of cars that drive themselves.</p> 
            <p>While the overall panel was about autonomous vehicles, they started off with a quick mention of the GT — Ford’s ridiculous (both in its ridiculous performance and in the ridiculously low number of them being made), $450,000 supercar. We spent an afternoon <a target="_blank" href="https://techcrunch.com/2017/05/11/a-day-on-the-track-with-the-ridiculous-2017-ford-gt-supercar/" rel="noopener noreferrer">checking out the GT</a> a few weeks back.</p> 
            <p>“Yeah.. that car is a little bit my baby,” said Nair. “But it’s kind of the opposite of a driverless vehicle.”</p> 
            <p>Nair elaborated on this a bit later when Darrell asked if we’d see a 100th anniversary GT (as this new GT is a 50th anniversary celebration of the original) — effectively, whether or not Ford would still be making human-driven vehicles in 50 years:</p> 
            <blockquote>
             <p>Technology is progressing fast. We’re 114 years old, and there are still aspects of the start of the automotive industry and what it meant for personal mobility. Horses don’t serve the role that they used to, but there’s still a lot of horse races that are a big deal, and people still enjoy riding horses. I hope it doesn’t go <em>that</em> far, but it’s certainly a possibility. I think there will always be an aspect of controlling a piece of machinery, of two or three thousand pounds of machinery being controlled by very minute movements of your hand… Taking yourself to the limit, taking the machine to the limit; there’s something in our brain wired to enjoy that, so hopefully that’s always a part of it.</p>
            </blockquote> 
            <p>While there will probably always be those who’ll want to drive themselves (if eventually only for sport), the industry trend toward figuring out autonomous vehicles seems clear. But this introduces a whole new challenge for the industry: if a vehicle can drive itself… you don’t necessarily need to <em>own</em> one, as you can just summon a car when you need it. Nair suggests they’re well aware of this, but it’s something on the horizon:</p> 
            <blockquote>
             <p>The pace at which the technology is advancing is faster than it’s ever been. It’s becoming more readily apparent to the broader public and the industry, and new entrants out in Silicon valley, and there’s a lot more players coming into it. I think on the usership side — the popularity of ride hailing, the ride sharing model, is increasing — yet, the aspect of personal ownership is still really, really high. We’re at a record industry of sales right now. I think we’ll see a distribution change over time, but that part of it’ll be gradual. Yet this industry operates on pretty long cycles, so we need to be planning for that right now.</p>
            </blockquote> 
            <p>But with just about every automotive maker cracking away at this challenge, how might Ford be the one to get it done? At least in part, by not insisting that they do it all themselves.</p>
            <div>
             <div id="adsDivacc5b65879" class="native-ad-mobile"></div>
            </div> 
            <p>“We’re not intent on doing it ourselves,” says Raj, mentioning their acquisitions (like SAIPS, the <a target="_blank" href="https://techcrunch.com/2016/08/16/ford-acquires-saips-for-self-driving-machine-learning-and-computer-vision-tech/" rel="noopener noreferrer">machine learning company Ford purchased in 2016</a>), licensing and investments — like Argo AI, a team Ford <a target="_blank" href="https://techcrunch.com/2017/02/18/ford-invests-in-pittsburgh-based-argo-ai-to-build-self-driving-cars-by-2021/" rel="noopener noreferrer">committed to investing $1 billion dollars into</a> over five years. “Probably the most sought-after talent in the autonomous space are the roboticists, the software experts and the machine learning experts… We have a very strong team internally, but to be honest, they were being very heavily recruited.”</p> 
            <p>Ford has already been experimenting with shared vehicles with Chariot, the ride-sharing service it <a target="_blank" href="https://techcrunch.com/2016/09/09/ford-mobility-solutions-acquires-chariot/" rel="noopener noreferrer">acquired last year</a>. If shared vehicles/routes becomes a sizeable part of Ford’s business, who owns that shared (and, presumably, eventually autonomous) fleet? Ford? Private entities? Municipalities? (As Darrell noted onstage, TechCrunch had previously heard that Ford was talking with municipalities about owning ridesharing fleets as they might own public transit.)</p> 
            <blockquote>
             <p>We’re experimenting with a couple different forms of that. Part of that is the Chariot experiment which we’re doing, where we’re owning fleets of transits, running shuttles and working with municipalities on some aspects of dynamic shuttles and dynamic routing, but also fixed routes at a smaller scale. And other city-as-customer pilots… I think we’re open to ownership of that fleet. We’re open to different models, and different discussions as to where ownership of that fleet would reside… We’re interested in managing those vehicles as a service, we’re interested in manufacturing those vehicles and we’d also be interested in the profit opportunity for transportation services.</p>
            </blockquote> 
            <p>So if Ford deeply embraces technology at deeper and deeper levels moving forward, will it keep its “Ford Motor” name or change it to something like “Ford Technology”?</p> 
            <blockquote>
             <p>I think we’re going to be called Ford Motor Company for a while. The company is attached to it — the family is attached to it… but I think Ford Motor Company will look very different 10 years from now. It’ll be known not just as an automotive company, but an automotive <em>and</em> mobility company.</p>
            </blockquote> 
            <!-- End: Wordpress Article Content --> 
           </div> 
           <a href="http://www.techcrunch.com/event-info/disrupt-ny-2017#tickets" class="event-after-article" data-ga-event="click" data-ga-event-category="Marketing - Internal" data-ga-event-action="After Article Graphic" data-ga-event-label="DisruptNY"> <img src="https://tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com/2016/11/disruptny17_1360x200.png"> </a> 
           <div id="social-after-wrapper" class="cf social-share social-share-inline"> 
            <ul class="inline-list social-share-list" id="social-after" data-permalink="https://techcrunch.com/2017/05/15/ford-cto-raj-nair-on-the-future-ford-will-look-very-different-in-ten-years/" data-shortlink="http://tcrn.ch/2pQ1b6e" data-sharetitle="Ford CTO Raj Nair on the future: Ford will look very different in 10&nbsp;years" data-post-id="1490522">

          <section class="aside section video-aside crunchreport collapse collapse-adjacent" data-video-id="591a1511f3bdc95a680de980"> 
           <h2 class="collapse-title section-title"> Latest <span>Crunch Report</span> </h2> 
           <div class="collapse-body cf"> 
            <ul class="vid-list cf"> 
             <li class="block vid-feature" data-lightbox-omniture="crunchreport"> 
              <div class="block block-inset"> 
               <a href="https://techcrunch.com/video/lyft-and-waymo-partner-up-on-self-driving-cars-crunch-report/591a1511f3bdc95a680de980/?ncid=rightrail_cr"> <img src="https://img.vidible.tv/prod/2017-05/15/591a1511f3bdc95a680de980/591a162e58415c1314d85f0d_o_U_v1.jpg?w=300&amp;h=170" alt="Lyft and Waymo Partner Up on Self-Driving Cars | Crunch Report" data-lightbox-url="https://techcrunch.com/video/lyft-and-waymo-partner-up-on-self-driving-cars-crunch-report/591a1511f3bdc95a680de980/lightbox"> 
                <div class="block-title">

  <script type="application/ld+json">
		{"@context":"http:\/\/schema.org","@type":"Article","url":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2017\/05\/15\/ford-cto-raj-nair-on-the-future-ford-will-look-very-different-in-ten-years\/","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Greg Kumparak"},"headline":"Ford CTO Raj Nair on the future: Ford will","articleBody":"\n\nToday at TechCrunch Disrupt NY, our own Darrell Etherington sat down with Ford Motor Company CTO (and Ford employee since 1987!) Raj Nair to chat about the future and how a company like Ford shifts with an evolving industry \u2014 particularly as the car industry adopts the idea of cars that drive themselves.\n\nWhile the overall panel was about autonomous vehicles, they started off with a quick mention of the GT \u2014 Ford's ridiculous (both in its ridiculous performance and in the ridiculously low number of them being made), $450,000 supercar. We spent an afternoon checking out the GT a few weeks back.\n\n\u201cYeah.. that car is a little bit my baby,\u201d said Nair. \u201cBut it\u2019s kind of the opposite of a driverless vehicle.\u201d\n\nNair elaborated on this a bit later when Darrell asked if we\u2019d see a 100th anniversary GT (as this new GT is a 50th anniversary celebration of the original) \u2014 effectively, whether or not Ford would still be making human-driven vehicles in 50 years:\n\nTechnology is progressing fast. We\u2019re 114 years old, and there are still aspects of the start of the automotive industry and what it meant for personal mobility. Horses don\u2019t serve the role that they used to, but there\u2019s still a lot of horse races that are a big deal, and people still enjoy riding horses. I hope it doesn\u2019t go that far, but it's certainly a possibility. I think there will always be an aspect of controlling a piece of machinery, of two or three thousand pounds of machinery being controlled by very minute movements of your hand... Taking yourself to the limit, taking the machine to the limit; there's something in our brain wired to enjoy that, so hopefully that's always a part of it.\n\nWhile there will probably always be those who'll want to drive themselves (if eventually only for sport), the industry trend toward figuring out autonomous vehicles seems clear. But this introduces a whole new challenge for the industry: if a vehicle can drive itself\u2026 you don't necessarily need to own one, as you can just summon a car when you need it. Nair suggests they're well aware of this, but it's something on the horizon:\n\nThe pace at which the technology is advancing is faster than it\u2019s ever been. It\u2019s becoming more readily apparent to the broader public and the industry, and new entrants out in Silicon valley, and there\u2019s a lot more players coming into it. I think on the usership side \u2014 the popularity of ride hailing, the ride sharing model, is increasing \u2014 yet, the aspect of personal ownership is still really, really high. We\u2019re at a record industry of sales right now. I think we\u2019ll see a distribution change over time, but that part of it\u2019ll be gradual. Yet this industry operates on pretty long cycles, so we need to be planning for that right now.\n\nBut with just about every automotive maker cracking away at this challenge, how might Ford be the one to get it done? At least in part, by not insisting that they do it all themselves.\n\n\"We're not intent on doing it ourselves,\" says Raj, mentioning their acquisitions (like SAIPS, the machine learning company Ford purchased in 2016), licensing and investments \u2014 like Argo AI, a team Ford committed to investing $1 billion dollars into over five years. \"Probably the most sought-after talent in the autonomous space are the roboticists, the software experts and the machine learning experts\u2026 We have a very strong team internally, but to be honest, they were being very heavily recruited.\"\n\nFord has already been experimenting with shared vehicles with Chariot, the ride-sharing service it acquired last year. If shared vehicles\/routes becomes a sizeable part of Ford's business, who owns that shared (and, presumably, eventually autonomous) fleet? Ford? Private entities? Municipalities? (As Darrell noted onstage, TechCrunch had previously heard that Ford was talking with municipalities about owning ridesharing fleets as they might own public transit.)\n\nWe\u2019re experimenting with a couple different forms of that. Part of that is the Chariot experiment which we\u2019re doing, where we\u2019re owning fleets of transits, running shuttles and working with municipalities on some aspects of dynamic shuttles and dynamic routing, but also fixed routes at a smaller scale. And other city-as-customer pilots\u2026 I think we\u2019re open to ownership of that fleet. We're open to different models, and different discussions as to where ownership of that fleet would reside... We\u2019re interested in managing those vehicles as a service, we\u2019re interested in manufacturing those vehicles and we\u2019d also be interested in the profit opportunity for transportation services.\n\nSo if Ford deeply embraces technology at deeper and deeper levels moving forward, will it keep its \"Ford Motor\" name or change it to something like \"Ford Technology\"?\n\nI think we're going to be called Ford Motor Company for a while. The company is attached to it \u2014 the family is attached to it\u2026 but I think Ford Motor Company will look very different 10 years from now. It'll be known not just as an automotive company, but an automotive and mobility company.\n\n","datePublished":"2017-05-15T20:54:16+00:00","mainEntityOfPage":"True","image":{"@list":["https:\/\/tctechcrunch2011.files.wordpress.com\/2017\/05\/tcdisrupt-ny17-8811.jpg"]},"speakable":{"@type":"SpeakableSpecification","cssSelector":[".alpha","#speakable-summary"]}}	</script>
